question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yoo encouraged pair shares where students were allowed to talk with their partners about discussion questions. We also conducted larger group discussions and had access to an interactive running document to keep notes. Students got an opportunity to present an introduction to the pre-work for the day. We also got pre readings and videos like excerpts to books and PBS documentaries. I liked how we had the option to write or send in questions beforehand, and I also like how we were able to talk in smaller groups before sharing to the whole class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course to take for T-Reqs, I learned a lot about not just Asian American history, but why Asian American as a term exists in the first place--it's a term that homogenizes Asians, and yet it's a ubiquitous term because of how similar and interconnected the histories of immigration to the US from each Asian country and the experience of Asian American immigrants are. Very insightful course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I enjoyed this course a lot! I felt like the course provided many opportunities to develop both creative and critical projects that I felt proud of. Many of the texts/films/media that we read throughout the class were familiar to me, but others were not. Regardless, the material covered in class helped me recontextualize those familiar works, and the unfamiliar ones added a new layer to my understanding of East Asian culture. The class also offers many opportunities to work with other students (casually, and more in-depth), and it was amazing to see what other students could contribute or what their interests were. This was a class where I learned from students as much as I did from Dr. Chow, Mingkang, and the readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The ability  to introspect within the past in real time and take those contemporary views and applying them to Iranian history in the modern sense. Understanding the countries history is a skill in itself considering how intricate it is.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read and analyze Persian poetry, and I learned about the history of Iran up to modern times.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to manage my time effectively when analyzing dense readings. I also learned the importance of language and critical thinking when receiving information from Westernized media regarding various cultures in the Middle East. I also learned how to think from a more philosophical level, especially in regards to spirituality. Expanding my mind in this way helped me understand Iran and their history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Prior to this course, I had very little knowledge about Iran and its history. In this course, I learned about famous Iranian poets (Rumi, Sa'di, Hafez), the rise of Shi'ism in Iran during the Safavid empire, and the conditions that led to the 1979 Iranian Revolution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class further taught me ways of thinking and viewing the world and to challenge more Western and orientalist narratives, and also to rethink what modernity is and who defines or has defined it. I learned about Iranian poetry, the revolution, and historical relations between the US and Iran and how that has been altered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I learned about the history of Iran
-I learned about why Iran is the way it is today (government and social life) 
-I learned how much Western powers, especially the US and Britain, influenced and hurt Iran in the past that heavily affected their current state.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I developed learning from different perspectives, which was something facilitated early on with our first reading of Jasmine and Stars. Outside of the Orientalist perspective that is sometimes favored in the West, my eyes were completely opened to the complexity and beauty of Iran from its beginning. I developed more close-reading skills, especially when it came to the translated Persian works that we read in Radical Love and Rose Garden. I found that by the end of the class, I could read these, and similar works, more quickly while being able to understand its relevance/meaning in the greater Sufi tradition.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better understanding of global politics, non-westernized view of Iran, and larger library of poetry.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

We also almost always started class talking about current events in the news, related or unrelated to Iran, which always set the mood for a thought-provoking class. Not having electronics also helped keep the class focused on the material. I really feel like this class would always fly by.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class was especially stimulating because what we learn in the West about Iran is often not the full story, so I found almost everything I learned in this class to actually prove wrong a lot of the preconceived notions that I had about Iran's history and culture. This made it so I always had lots of questions about the material, which I always came in to class prepared with, in addition to questions posed by the in-class lectures. I also liked that we went in chronological order considering the things we were learning about present-day Iran made sense considering what we had learned about Persian history/culture from the very beginning. I wish that we had a little more organized lecture/Powerpoint introduction to the topics we focused on earlier in the class; I found it really helpful later on when we started talking about the Shah/revolution, and think it could have been effective in portraying earlier themes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how the World Wars shaped the development of states in the Middle East
2) I learned, through Dr. Gemeah's personal accounts of the Arab Spring and watching Operation Iraqi Freedom on television, how people native to the region interpreted US involvement post-9/11
3) I learned about state secularization efforts in Iran and Turkey and how the two regions had similar motivations but vastly different outcomes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Gained basic understanding of the development of the Middle East as a region and major historic forces behind it. Was introduced to a variety of primary sources and learned to engage with them. Improved my skills of source analysis and historical writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of knowledge of the early history of the Middle East (ie. Ottoman Empire), and how this period connects to modern history. I also learned how to critically analyze primary sources, especially films, and how to accurately use these sources in a paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I developed more skills in finding and understanding both sides of a perspective, as well as just knowing more about how visual and written primary sources are equally as helpful in understanding history. Additionally, I think I gained more insight into the US' role in the Middle East and how it is often not as it is presented to the American public.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course greatly enhanced my critical thinking and my ability to draw connections between seemingly disparate historical events and trends. My understanding of the US's relationship with the Middle East grew tremendously and this course expanded my capacity for empathy in thinking about certain political movements that I previously disagreed with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I always thought of the middle east as very separate from the western world, and this course taught me that that is completely false. I have taken a lot of history courses that focus on ancient history, so taking one that extended to the modern day gave me a really complete picture of how exactly the modern situations have been created.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I developed my critical thinking skills as well as my discussion skills. This course required debate and discussion regarding the sources we studied for homework.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to analyze film beyond the plot, focusing on visual elements like framing and color to understand deeper meanings. I also gained insight into how Chinese cinema reflects regional and historical shifts, especially through directors like Jia Zhangke. Lastly, I learned to appreciate minimalism and silence in film as powerful storytelling tools. Before this class, I had no experience with film analysis, and, quite frankly, did not appreciate them to the level that I do now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about how to watch movies through a critical lens by examining the sound design and the cinematography. I also learned about how to place the films in a historical context surrounding Hong Kong, Taiwan, and China. I also learned about a bunch of new directors and their style.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, the biggest knowledge I gained was about East Asian cinema in general, including how political, social, and economic factors shape film and how filmmaking conventions vary by region---I was really interested by the Taiwanese New Cinema movement especially. Additionally, I learned how to analyze films and talk about films in an academic way, paying close attention to cinematography, sound, script, etc. Finally, I learned about many directors I had never heard of before that I now love to watch!

response_text: I learned how to more deeply analyze, consume, and appreciate the works of 9 film directors. More specifically, I learned about how color, cinematography, framing, sound, and narrative structure influence the meaning and consumption of the film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to analyze films in terms of not just the plot but also the cinematography and the style of the director. I have also learned to create a short film through collaborations with my teammates and participate in constructive discussion in class about Chinese cinema.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was awesome! Emily's enthusiasm for the class and the material is evident and contagious. She was an incredibly approachable, flexible, and caring professor and created an environment where it felt like we were really able to think critically while also having fun in a low-stakes environment. The course's selected topics and the sequence in which these topics were presented were logical and coherent. I appreciated that Emily took the time to contextualize each new topic we discussed within the scope of what we had learned thus far. Topics were well-connected and referenced each other, which gave me a deeper appreciation for the course's ethnomusicological lens and each of the individual musics. Emily did a fantastic job of fostering a friendly and supportive class environment. Despite the larger class size, it felt like we were able to have discussions, share ideas, and get to know each other's ways of thinking. Emily also seemed genuinely interested in learning from us, fostering a non-hierarchical classroom environment (versus one where the professor clearly presents as the all-knowing expert uninterested in students' insights) that I think greatly encouraged students' independent thinking. Karaoke was a lot of fun and also helped build camaraderie among the class. I think all of the assignments were meaningful and useful while also leaving plenty of room for our own thinking and creativity (e.g. 3 you pick listening journals and a very open-ended final project). Course assignments were structured in a way that leaves options and appeals to a diversity of strengths and weaknesses (e.g. appealing to those who prefer test-taking vs. essay-writing and to those who prefer independent vs group work). Most of all, this class was fun! It's such a relief to have a class that is genuinely fun, where the professor is also excited to just have fun while still learning a lot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how much music we had to listen to. The listening reflection/listening journal was really fun, because it's pretty informal but still requires a level of understanding of musicology concepts. Final project is fun and I like Prof Wang's openness to all sorts of projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it -- no matter if you are Asian or speak any Asian language. From the modern pop music in Asia (well, East Asia to be more exact) and Asian America, you actually learn tremendously about the historical reason behind why certain music sounds like a certain way coming from these countries and cultures, and it's a methodology extremely applicable to analyzing the music of other geographies -- we do a lot of cross cultural analysis in music beyond just Asian music as well.

response_text: I learned a lot about Islamic religion and culture I never knew before, such as how Muslims greatly differed in their style of interpretation of scripture and how their scripture was revealed; I learned about how there is no such thing as a single scripture or a shared belief because religion changes constantly and is constantly interpreted; I learned that each Abrahamic faith has a specific tradition of interpretation.

response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze texts and apply them across different cultures. I learned how to write well thought through research papers. I learned how to engage with different opinions than my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about Islamic religion and culture I never knew before, such as how Muslims greatly differed in their style of interpretation of scripture and how their scripture was revealed; I learned about how there is no such thing as a single scripture or a shared belief because religion changes constantly and is constantly interpreted; I learned that each Abrahamic faith has a specific tradition of interpretation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how complex religion and scripture is 
- the importance of understanding the limitations of scripture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. Learning about the three different major monotheistic religions is learning three specific things in and of themselves. Learning about religion in a historical context is one of the most interesting things to learn and I've learned to shift my thinking from a theological prespective to a historical critical one. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the evolution of the three main Abrahamic texts. I learned how scripture is interpreted, who interprets it, and how that has shaped the communities of different religions. I learned how to be a historic critic of religious texts and why that role is ESSENTIAL to understanding society and religion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how scriptures of Islam, Christianity, and Judaism are compiled and interpreted. I also learned about the basic structure of each religious text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Reading scripture as "a book" rather than a religious text
Learned different methods of interpretation
learned the history that led to the evolution of these different interpretations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at scriptures from a historical and critical perspective rather than a religious one
I learned about the canonization of each scripture and the complexities behind each
I learned of how each of the religions cope with issues and how they try to modernize

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to distinguish between religion and scripture from a scholarly perspective. We learned different words in Greek, Hebrew, and Arabic. We also learned about different key figures in each religious tradition.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the reading to help facilitate learning in lectures and I also appreciated that we had a guided reflection to fill out about the readings. It held me accountable to do my readings and engage with them. I also just enjoyed the overall structure of the class and how it would shift from each religion and how there would aslo be days where our professors would teach on a common topic. Additional to the structure I enjoyed that there were only two major assignments to do throughout the whole semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were "good" for the most part. It's definitely the right idea, but sometimes the instructions were vague and the links were hard to find. I would certainly keep these graded readings, and expand on the feedback. The lectures were always excellent and the professors always came OVERLY prepared. It was impressive and refreshing to be taught by professors who had too many slides and could talk for hours on their subject. Don't change a thing about the lectures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The reading responses  also helped us come into class with a basis of knowledge on the subject that was to be discussed that day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures themselves were often quite interesting. The humor and style of the presentations were fun as well. The sensitivity and content with which the professors approached religious topics made for a good learning environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, my analysis and critical thinking skills developed. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the historical developments in Chinese medicine such as through the different dynasties and how changing social, political, economic, etc. factors shaped and impacted these developments
2) I learned about the creation of TCM as state medicine and the tension between tradition and modernization in terms of Chinese medicine
3) I learned about how Chinese medicine was implemented in the United States and how Chinese medicine practices and practitioners adjusted to new environments

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

2. I learned a lot about the barefoot doctors in China, which was one of my favorite topics we went over!
3. I learned a lot about how to think when approaching integration and Westernization vs. modernization

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much more about ancient and early modern Japanese history. I also learned more about analyzing primary documents and how to effectively discuss them and synthesize them with secondary sources.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: It was interesting learning about the history of Japan. I think the biggest skill I took away from this experience was critical thinking, as in understanding the complexities of historical documentation. I also learned how to pick apart a text from a historical narrative. I think that in other classes it's more geared toward understanding an essence, and while it still holds for historical documents, you also need to immerse yourself in the time the event occurred to truly understand it. I also broaden my way of thinking, which I think has become more fluid and less rigid because of the course.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about all aspects of ancient Japanese culture. I went into this course knowing literally nothing about Japan and I came out of it with a pretty good understanding of the development of their society.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The way of thinking I developed during this course was unique to other classes. I learned that to understand history you have to understand there are different perspectives and that not everything is black and white. As an example, although women faced massive amounts of discrimination throughout ancient Japanese history there are extraordinary examples of women being leaders, writers, and equals in society. Three specific things I learned was different art forms (Nō, Kabuki, etc), societal systems, and the relationships Japan had with outside states (Korea, China, Netherlands etc)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: When reading through the Masnavi/Memorial of God's Friends it may sometimes be helpful to search up references to the Qur'an/figures and events in Islamic history in order to better understand the text. The Masnavi contains a reference in the back that is especially important to look up, since Rumi makes many metaphors and references that those not familiar with aspects of the Islamic faith are likely to miss. Attar is more comprehensible but he is by nature a poet, and so should also be read in this way.Read the texts very carefully.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this class. Professor Schanzer is so wise and knows how to spark a class debate. He pushed back on every comment to lead students to think deeper. Even if he agreed with their point he knew how to counter it. One of the biggest lessons I took away is that not every question has a clear answer but the process of thinking through them is what leads to true understanding.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Aftermath of 9/11
- Construction and complexities of the American security and intelligence apparatus following 9/11
- Intricacies of the American foreign policy and military approach to the Middle East (Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya, Syria, Arab Spring, etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think on my feet better, be prepared with readings, and advanced my critical thinking skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I thin my ability to synthesize sources and conclude nuanced and thorough analyses was strengthened in this class. I also felt more comfortable/confident in participating in big group discussions. I also learned so much historical, religious, and geopolitical context about the US, the Middle East, and foreign and domestic policy after 9/11.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about the social and political tensions that led to the 9/11 attacks, as well as the US's post-attack foreign policy and engagement in the Middle East.
2. I learned how to critically analyze and critique US foreign policy and think through the contingencies surrounding 9/11 and its aftermath. 
3. I gained insight on how to apply the historical lessons learned from 9/11 to contemporary conflicts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about foreign policy in the United States through the lens of executive power. I learned a lot about Islamic principles and how life works in the Middle East. I improved my ability to write concisely and argumentatively when taking a stance on a policy issue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to think critically about how decisions that were made in the best interest of the United States in the moment of terror have rippling effects on much of our politics today. I learned about the different presidential administrations and their responses to the "War on Terror" and how the framing of war has an impact on outcomes. I also learned about the history of Afghanistan and the Middle East, which I had previously been unfamiliar with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I strengthened my ability to form a clear and well-structured argumentative essay, I became a better debater speaking up in class when I disagreed/agreed, and I strengthened my ability to form my own opinions about the topics given the materials we were assigned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- General knowledge about terrorism, as well as specific knowledge related to both the causes and historical context of 9/11 as well as American response domestically and internationally. 
- The legalese behind executive orders, use of military force, and gray area judicial processes. 
- How to weigh and evaluate security versus liberty.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class forced me to think critically about how difficult foreign policy can be. It helped me to understand the last two decades of U.S. intervention abroad in the context of 9/11. I have come to see 9/11 not just as a tragic isolated event, but rather the beginning of a new era of American politics: the War on Terror did not end with our withdrawal from Iraq, it just wears a different hat now.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Schanzer is an incredible teacher, not just because he is beyond knowledgeable about this topic, but also because he pushes his students to be better, in every sense of the word. I really appreciated how he goes out of his way to facilitate meaningful discussion inside (and outside of class). Instead of just asking discussion questions in class he encourages us to dig deeper by challenging the points we make. For our midterm assignments we are provided with copious amounts of helpful feedback that we and then encouraged to use when revising out essays. This process has made me a better writer and challenged me to put more thought and care into my written assignments. Above all things academic I truly believe that Professor Schanzer cares deeply about his students success and well being. He is always willing to meet outside of class and take great care to get to know his students. Overall Professor Schanzer is a great teacher and he teaches a great course!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The purely discussion based nature of this class based on readings that we did outside of class made it so my learning was compounded. Professor Schanzer would start each class with a question that would lead to the remaining time being spent in discussion with students building off of each others' ideas or disagreeing with points made. The way that everyone was encouraged to share their reactions/ideas based on the readings made it so I would come in to class thinking one way, and always leave class with new ideas about different policies, military actions, presidential decisions, etc.. I would definitely keep the discussion sections in following years, and maybe even reverting back to a smaller class size to encourage participation. Having Ken was super helpful too in having someone present that was actually in Afghanistan/Iraq and could speak on the military aspects of the conflicts before and after 9/11. Having a CTTP fellow next year with a similar background would be great. Also I really liked how we went in chronological order all the way back thousands of years, at first I was confused what Sayyid Qutb would have to do with 9/11 all the way back in the 1930s, but then it all made sense.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Schanzer was challenging but in a very constructive way. He made it clear that he held us to high standards in our writing and classroom discussions, so we felt pushed to put in our best work. Therefore, my engagement in this class was higher than usual, as I knew I would be challenged and wanted to succeed/meet Schanzer's approval. Schanzer is also very skilled at facilitating discussions, prompting and challenging our opinions and forcing us to think more deeply about complicated issues.I also really liked the structure and flow of the course and how we zoomed in on different topics--contemporary or historical--while also maintaining a broad understanding of the necessary background info, i.e., the history of Muslim civilization. My favorite topic we zoomed in on was probably the Israel Palestine discussion. I did not have much to add personally that day since I did not have much background info, but I really benefitted from hearing what my classmates with differing opinions had to say, as well as Schanzer's insight. I also liked the homegrown terrorism and TSA/airport discussions a lot, as my classmates and I had a lot of differing views and personal experiences with these topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The class was stimulating because the material itself has been very contested over the years. Especially because policy is inherently political; therefore, we usually were dealing with topics that had at least two sides. Professor Schanzer pushed back on everyone, no matter what side they were taking, encouraging to consider things from another perspective. He would always respond to our points with "what about when this happened..." or "so you're saying..." and it always made us think more about what we said in the context of things we might not have considered in our conclusions. I think the discussion sections were especially good for this because I got to hear more people speak in a more intimate environment, which always helped challenge my thoughts even when it wasn't Prof Schanzer/Ken directly asking me follow up questions. 
Also rewrites are an awesome opportunity to get critical feedback and rework some of our ideas.

It was very cool when we were given specific, more personal anecdotes to read/watch as those are extra engaging, i.e., the video on terrorist recruitment. Whenever Ken shared his personal experiences with class topics was also fascinating. I already mentioned really liking the flow of the course topics, but Schanzer was really good at laying everything out for us in a very structured way that was helpful for me to visualize.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of reading but do not let that intimidate you. Professor Schanzer goes out of his way to make relationships with his students—even hosting a group dinner at the end of the course. This is a course that will challenge you and force you to think about the topics outside of the classroom.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
This class is a large workload and you have to do the readings. It means that you will be incredibly knowledgeable about 9/11 afterwards, but oftentimes I was overwhelmed and stressed by the sheer amount of work I had to do and the difficulty in formulating responses to essays. Professor Schanzer will not sugarcoat his feedback, which is very helpful, but also means that sometimes essay feedback can feel a little disheartening. 
If you're interested in national security and American foreign policy, I highly recommend this course. If you would like to analyze America's response to 9/11 through a more progressive, human rights centric lens, this course does not delve deep into that topic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Ralph Litzinger is the most admirable and appreciated teacher I have encountered at Duke. His courses are rich, profound, and thought-provoking, showcasing his passion and dedication to teaching in every session. Beyond the classroom, Professor Litzinger genuinely cares about his students' growth and development. During moments when I felt lost and uncertain, his support and encouragement helped me regain my motivation and confidence. His guidance has not only advanced my academic journey but also brought me courage and strength in life. Being his student is one of the most treasured experiences of my time at Duke, and his influence will forever remain in my memory. Professor Ralph Litzinger is truly an irreplaceable mentor.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the politics and representations of nationalism, identity, ethnicity, and religion. By combining a set of varied texts and issues, I developed a more complex understanding of geopolitics and culture in the Middle East. I also became more familiar with important debates that continue to inform the Middle East today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about historical comparative analyses, forms of quasi state-building, and the role of Islam in constructing theocracies post-Ottoman empire.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was AMAZING! It was a totally new type of history class for me, as it was organized largely by theoretical topics (nation state formation, feminist critique , et.c), rather than necessarily by chronology or geography. I seriously learned so much in this course about how to look at the world and history through different critical lenses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One piece of knowledge I gained was that I now know about the role of colonial states in the formation of the modern Middle East. The next thing I learned was that I am very capable of handling tougher classes here at 
Duke. Lastly I learned more about state formation theory and how it's still relevant today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I started this class knowing relatively little about middle eastern history or politics. I learned about:
- The development of the state of Turkey
- How current states formed in the ME
- Islamist ideology
- Muslim feminist ideology

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained lots of new knowledge about the Ottoman Empire and the Modern Middle East. I learned about processes required in state formation, and how historical empires / rulers set precedent for emerging nations. I learned about different eras of the Ottoman rule, as well as the empire's legacies. I learned about both overlap and unique qualities of the formation of several Middle Eastern states. I also learned about the formation, success, and challenges of several major terrorist organizations in the region. I learned how themes of religion, gender, and ethnicity contribute to the foundations of several of these states.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Goknar was fantastic at developing class discussion. He always introduced complexity into our discussions and expanded on ideas. Our readings were incredibly interesting and informative. Prof. Goknar was incredible, and always made class interesting and informative.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it covers a wide range of literature on the Middle East and students get the chance to engage with challenging readings on the subject. It could be made more intellectually stimulating by having the professor discuss more about the readings rather than have students read off the slides, but overall an interesting course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were stimulating as well as Professor Goknar's knowledge. He was very well educated on all the topics we discussed, and made me eager to listen and contribute.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: On the first day of class, I was worried I would have to drop out because it seemed very difficult. I came in with no knowledge about the history of the middle east, and Professor Goknar wastes no time diving into the deep end of the content. However, this turned out to be extremely rewarding, and I think that taking challenging courses is the entire point of college. Professor Goknar chooses interesting material that I am excited to learn about, and presents it in an accessible and enthusiastic way. Although the content is sometimes challenging, it is incredibly stimulating, and Professor Goknar is kind in his grading so that I was never worried about failing this course, only working harder.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class stimulating were discussions that would happen in response to our readings, just hearing different opinions and perspectives helped me improve and increase my knowledge.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class went above and beyond by providing very nuanced, complex, and informative content. I always left class feeling more knowledgeable, even if the topic of the day was difficult or complicated. The readings were well chosen and the topics were interesting. I want to concretely express that Professor Goknar was one of the best professors I’ve had at Duke, and he absolutely should be considered for an award.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we learned to examine history through a personal lens by analyzing memoirs and primary sources from varying perspectives. We also learned to engage in texts by completing weekly reading responses. Lastly, we learned to pull out thematic patterns and common threads over the course of Israeli-Palestinian history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Learning to think about how to make compromises between groups with so much animosity was incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach the Israeli-Palestinian conflict with numerous perspectives. I learned how to write critically and analyze readings. I also learned the deep history of the conflict which I didn't know existed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I left the class with my analytical writing skills much better than they were previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should absolutely sign up for this course.  Dr. Weinthal and Dr. Stein are tremendous teachers who help break down the complexity of the Israel/Palestine conflict without ever minimizing the difficulties of it.  The class will teach you so much about human rights, natural resources, state-building, and the history of one of the most visible global conflicts.  You won't just learn about what happened, you will be asked to engage directly with thehuman dimensions of this conflict and confront the difficult realities of the past and current situation.  This class is a must take.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we learned to examine history through a personal lens by analyzing memoirs and primary sources from varying perspectives. We also learned to engage in texts by completing weekly reading responses. Lastly, we learned to pull out thematic patterns and common threads over the course of Israeli-Palestinian history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me so much more context to understand the situation in Israel-Palestine and helped me to develop the skills to approach understanding longstanding conflict. Learning to think about how to make compromises between groups with so much animosity was incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach the Israeli-Palestinian conflict with numerous perspectives. I learned how to write critically and analyze readings. I also learned the deep history of the conflict which I didn't know existed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I left the class with my analytical writing skills much better than they were previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was amazing. I learned how to read through deep philosophical text and analyze them into insightful discussion posts, building upon other posts and contributing to a philosophical discussion. Another area in which I developed was the ability to view multiple different perspectives within the philosophical discussion and figure out what I truly believed and how to be constructive about what information you were believing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how a different part of the world thinks about ethics, virtue, human nature, and governance. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a great deal about Chinese Philosophy as a discipline specifically, but more than that, I learned about the story of ancient Chinese philosophical canon. The ways in which these philosophers and philosophical schools engaged in dialectics, what they held to be true, and how they impacted society (and especially governance) as we knew it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: different school of thoughts in early modern Chinese philosophy; the discourses and some key contentions in Chinese philosophy; the philosophical method that is highly transferrable to other schools of philosophy thoughts in other geographies.

response_text: The discussion posts were the highlight and should arguably be influenced even more. Towards the end of the year when one post would turn into a debate or conversation on the conversation page was amazing. I would try and reach that point where people are commenting on others posts in a natural way to appear sooner and more often in the semester, this would also give students more opportunity to participate in the lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Wong was good at bringing in student commentary into the lectures. We'd all be required to submit commentary in advance, before the lectures, and then he'd engage us in discussion in class at the appropriate places in the presentation, asking us to defend our positions and perhaps discuss them with classmates who, on the discussion board, expressed conflicting views. That was a good component.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: No handholds, in the best possible way. Prof. Wong jumps straight into the materially and discusses it with you on an even playing field, encourages you to familiarize yourself quickly so you can engage with the discussion. And in truth, it would be hard to make these texts boring as long as you represented them fairly. Also, having the opportunity to dissect and debate the professors own journal articles is great.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take, even if you don't know Chinese language or culture because you don't need to at all. It is just a philosophy course, and an amazing one at that. Engaging in philosophy has been such a beneficial experience for me, and frankly I think a philosophy course ought to be required for every student, especially considering the course requirement changes being made.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it. Light on work, not because the course is easy, but because the professor trusts you to spend time grappling with these topics yourself rather than doing endless assignments on them. IF you understand something, five pages should be enough to talk about it to an informed reader.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You get what you want to put into the class, if you're interested in philosophy, either as a major or just an interest, I think this class is an excellent introduction into the general ideas and themes found within Chinese philosophy. I'd recommend for those who want to engage with the content, most of it is going to be from internal reflection and consideration and some from class discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yoo encouraged pair shares where students were allowed to talk with their partners about discussion questions. We also conducted larger group discussions and had access to an interactive running document to keep notes. Students got an opportunity to present an introduction to the pre-work for the day. We also got pre readings and videos like excerpts to books and PBS documentaries. I liked how we had the option to write or send in questions beforehand, and I also like how we were able to talk in smaller groups before sharing to the whole class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I just want to shout out to Dr. Choudhury. Her arrangement of the readings and class materials is amazing. She used various assignments to effectively challenge us to think outside the box and creatively connect our personal lived experiences to what we learned in class. Her instruction is fantastic, eye-opening, and insightful. She made sure that the classroom was a safe space for knowledge exchange and open discussion, but she also guided us to think at a deeper and more intersectional level. She's one of the best instructors I have in my undergrad!! (And universities, she will be an amazing professor in the classroom!)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course I developed critical reading analysis skills, specifically looking at thematic ideas within Pamuk's novels. Furthermore, I deepened my understanding of Turkish and Ottoman history, specifically how Islam and current events relate back to the Ottoman period.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage critically with texts and connect fictional stories to historical and political contexts. I also learned more about the formation of Turkish national identity and how this affects the modern-day nation. Finally, I learned how to read Pamuk's work and the key attributes of his writing; I also learned how his writing fit in to broader contexts and connected with other media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

2. Gained more insight into the Turkish sociopolitical landscape.
3. Learned how to analytically think and interpret post-modern literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a strong ability to research and synthesize information.I learned a great deal about general Turkish history, and of the formation and central conflicts of the Turkish Republic.I learned a lot about literary analysis and of the main contemporary and classic Turkish writers, and how their national identity intersects with their work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think it was a great atmosphere to learn in with a lot of evaluation standards. I liked how we had a diverse number of evaluation techniques, and I liked the discussions and insights Dr. Goknar provided as we reviewed the required material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
We had very many different forms of learning in class, it was not a slideshow reading class at all.
I would keep the going up to the board to review part because it is very helpful to be put on the spot to see how much you really understood/remember.
I would also keep the cinema element in one of the units we did as it helped tie everything we were reading with great films.
I liked that the quizzes were on paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The drop-2 grading policy for writing assignments and quizzes was highly encouraging, and took a lot of the pressure off of experimentation. The course highly values originality and the ability to not only extrapolate value from the material but meaningfully synthesize it with other topics, develop an argument, and learn the rhetoric to portray that argument effectively. Göknar is very approachable and helpful and when I felt lost in the course (which was somewhat frequent), he always took time to point me int he right direction.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want a BS course to get an easy A in, don't take this course. If you want to learn and actually get something out of your classes this is an excellent course. Dr. Goknar has been my favorite Duke professor because I have learned so much from him. If he didn't expect so much from his students I wouldn't have actually learned anything. Relative to other Duke courses, this is one of the most rewarding classes because it pushes you to be the best student you can be.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Furthermore, you get acclimated to the amount of reading that is required (in the beginning), and so it does not become as much of a drag on your free time as you think it might.

response_text: This is the most rewarding class I've ever taken at Duke. If you want to develop niche interests and learn more about Turkish cultural history, definitely take this course. Don't be afraid of the difficulty and the workload because it is so interesting that most of the work doesn't even feel like work and you really end up feeling like a smarter and more analytical person by the end of each class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

There is a *lot* of information presented in this course and once you really go down the path of one topic, the rest start to click into place.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The work that was done with Derrida and deconstruction helped me to develop greater critical thinking skills as it broadened my mindset and consider how the definitions and norms that we think of today can be reconstructed or questioned based on their rationale and validity. Our time on Kant and Mahmood has helped me to consider the role that ethics might truly play. Most poignantly, the idea that American ethics in doing no harm is not truly virtue. Instead, considering how I might reconsider my own decisions and everyday life in the pursuit of cultivating virtue. Finally, Althusser and Foucault have allowed me to question the origins of the various norms that I take for granted.

By having two different professors with two different perspectives and teaching methods, I really got a feel for the diversity and plurality of the Arab World and the issues that are important to it.

Additionally, I learned how to be an adaptable student because most of this course was unstructured and we rarely knew what the plan was. Finally, the knowledge I have gained from this course has been immeasurable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: "I would not recommend this course to future students. While visiting the pyramids was a highlight, the overall experience was stressful and lacked the immersive, enriching quality one would hope for in a study abroad program. The professor was not understanding of students’ well-being, often disregarding exhaustion, illness, or logistical delays, and dismissing concerns with comments like 'you're a Duke student.' His teaching style included frequent irrelevant rants and unsolicited political commentary, which made many students uncomfortable. Additionally, much of the course content felt repetitive and unimpactful — visiting similar sites repeatedly without meaningful academic engagement. Weekend trips were exhausting and rushed, leaving little time to actually take in the experiences. The professor was largely absent outside of class and trips, and offered little personal engagement with students.On top of this, there were unexpected out-of-pocket costs that added up quickly, even for group meals that were supposed to be included. Given the high program cost, this was frustrating. Assignment deadlines were rigid, regardless of student health or circumstances, and there was a clear lack of empathy when students were sick or overwhelmed.Honestly, there’s so much about this program that could be talked about for hours — from the disorganization to the exhausting schedule, to the uncomfortable moments with the professor. If I could do it over, I would choose a different study abroad program that better balances academic rigor with cultural immersion and student well-being. The photos might look nice, but they don’t reflect the reality of the experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The workload is greater than some of the other abroad programs, but it is definitely worth it if you are interested in the topic. Professor Lo is an amazing lecturer and presents ideas in an easily accessable and applicable way. He transformed the way I though about middle eastern politics. I can not thank him enough for the amazing program and course. Definately take the class and program if you can.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The course may seem intimidating especially if you don't have any prior exposure to public policy classes, but as long as you have some interest in the middle east, its history, and how this reflects the current governments and relations, this class will not be difficult or hard to keep up the pace with.

There is a decent amount of reading required, but it is doable as long as you carve out time for it between all of the trips and excursions. This is a real course with real content that will broaden your horizons and deepen your knowledge on the Arab world while expanding the way you think and debunking misconceptions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

It pushed me to interact with a variety of texts, from essays of post-colonial scholars, to novels.
