What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: That honorifics are way more complex than indicating just politeness, how to analyze and critique research in linguistics, how to create linguistic experiments, how to teach Japanese language

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot more about the linguistic portion of the Japanese language.
2. I learned how linguistic journals are written about another language in English (which is super helpful if one wants to study another language but publish in the U.S.)
3. I learned how to skim, summarize, and find research gaps in current papers, which allowed me to gain some skills that would be necessary as a future linguist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: critical evaluation of academic literature, understanding of linguistic pragmatics and nuances in language usage under different contexts, designing research and experimental methods

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned what the field of linguistics is and about the history/current state of research in Japanese linguistics, learned how to identify problems in studies, as well as how to think about and design good studies for the future, learned more about differences between native Japanese speakers and learners as well as identified unconscious/conscious choices these learners make, conducted a study in the field of Japanese linguistics and learned how to deal with problems in study design, research, and data.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: For each class meeting, there is a paper to read in advance to allow for discussion during class time, which facillitated my thinking into how a research might want to conduct a similar experiment with a more grounded motivation and rigorous methodology.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We read a lot of literature on the subject and were asked to critique the papers. While sometimes I had trouble coming up with critiques beyond the usual "the sample size is small" or "the results are not generalizable," I think this overall approach to reading papers allowed us to think critically about how to best set up a research experiment while also recognizing that there is no one-size-fits-all experiment that has no weaknesses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the consistency of the course. You read two journal articles every week and practice the same skills. It allows students to acquire the skills necessary to read the papers but also understand them at a steady pace, which some professors ignore. I would definitely keep this part.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have learned Japanese before, it's very insightful and gives you context about your learning experience. The class sets you up so that you've read so many papers and you've conducted your own research that you can create a thesis out of it, and Professor Chen is very supportive of this thesis route.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You don't have to be a linguistics major to be in this class—reading the papers every week might be really difficult at first, but you will not be the only one struggling with the steep learning curve. But once you get used to it, you'll learn a lot more about the Japanese language than if you only take the Japanese language classes. Plus, you get to do your own research project, which is good experience for any university student.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history of Chinatowns, understood their role in local community and their global implications, and analyzed different components of them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at the historical context of Chinatowns in order to see how and why they exist
I learned that Chinatown is more than a fixed place in space that serves simply as a material existence
I learned how to call into question what it means to be "Chinese" and what constitutes for identity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Not only was the content we learned very rich, learning about the history of Chinese immigration (paper sons, wives) and how Chinese communities formed in America, we also learned how to critically engage with the sources we read, to think about whose stories get told in what manner. Who gets excluded, and why?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about flows of Chinese migration not just to the US, but also to Southeast Asia, and also other cities, including in Latin America, particularly through our first Chinatown assignment. Learned about different perspectives on Chinatowns from its residents (e.g. women, blue-collar and white-collar workers, recent and past immigrants, students). Considered methodologies of acquiring histories of marginalized populations and how in turn shapes our understanding of such populations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First and foremost, I learned about Chinatowns. There was a Chinatown in the city I grew up in, and I went every so often, but I never thought about its history much. I think the overall history of Chinese immigration was also something I learned. However, I enjoyed that we did not learn about Chinatowns as an individual idea, but rather as a continuous place of growing and transference of culture and knowledge, maintaining a connection with China and places all over the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about chinatowns as interconnected communities, analyizing immigrant patterns, contexts of that in relation to class, gender, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me a lot of new ways to think about the Chinese diaspora in general. For example, I learned about the history of Chinese immigration to America and the various issues and goings-on that were common in early Chinatowns. I also learned about more ways to examine "contemporary" topics such as interracial romance, higher education, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of the best courses I have taken at Duke! I learned all about the patterns of migration, whether one has the ability to opt out of identity, and how political events shape perceptions of identity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about new frameworks in which to view past events, and learned about a whole new context behind Chinatowns and the emigration of early Chinese settlers to the US that I never considered before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the history of chinatowns, i learned how to draw deep insights from information i learned, also it was great to be able to read complicated scholarly articles and see what connections i can draw.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the historical foundations of Chinatowns and the Chinese diaspora, ranging from 11th century migration to Nanyang (the Chinese term for Southeast Asia), through the 1850s goldrushes in America and Australia that spurred large scale migration, up until the modern day impetus for migration away from China. We learned about the politics of "Chineseness" and what the political work of calling something a Chinatown means considering the derogatory connotations of the term historically. We also learned about the culinary scene of the Chinese diaspora and interrogated notions of "autheniticity", "hybridity", and "fusion."

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned more about immigrants' experiences on their journey to the United States.
2. I learned about how to write a food ethnography.
3. I learned about how to many different aspects of Chinatowns around the world.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There are weekly discussions and readings that are super interesting. In addition, there is a food and chinatown ethnography project that let you dive deep into a Chinatown and restaurant, and lastly there is a roleplaying-type game. As someone who doesn't typically enjoy the nature of role-playing games/debate style, I found it extremely fun and interesting, and I wouldn't let this dissuade anyone from taking the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment was excellent! I always felt comfortable participating in class. The class was incredibly interactive. I would keep all elements of the course. The presentation really helped me learn about the complex history of a Chinatown of our choice. The restaurant ethnography was a fantastic way of learning how to interview others and explore the culture of a space. The game was incredibly exciting, and it taught us how to put ourselves in the shoes of people with different interests at stake (e.g., businessmen, professors, activists, etc.). Professor Chow tried to facilitate events outside of class, like a Hotpot outing, which really helped build class community. She was an incredible lecturer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had town-hall style classes where Dr. Chow would give a presentation for the first 20-30 minutes (or longer depending on the day) and it would segue into more natural Q&A style things. We got to do our own research projects on specific Chinatowns, as well as write an ethnographic essay of a Chinese restaurant. The most fun part of class, as well as the most engaging was the three-week long Chinatown game where we all inhabited the roles of different stakeholders in LA Chinatown.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take this course! You learn so much about life and Asian American identity. You learn about the history of Chinatowns and how this history intersects with global identity. Professor Chow is incredibly nice, and the assignments are very fascinating. There are three major assignments: a presentation on the history of a Chinatown, a restaurant ethnography (interview a restaurant owner and write an ethnography), and a role-play game. The workload is very manageable, and Professor Chow really encourages you to think outside the box. This course was such a wonderful experience. Take it!!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
- I wish that the professor could have listed all the readings on the syllabus beforehand. I didn't realize the professor didn't until it was too late.  There were only general topics but I had no idea about how much reading was expected of us (more than 100 pages of academic journals per week). The same goes for the collaborative mini projects, which had no due dates, which made it difficult to plan ahead. I did not like how one was due shortly after spring break. Overall, I did not like how the syllabus was not clear. The professor posted each batch of readings a few weeks before and I had no idea what or how much was expected. 
- I did not enjoy how classes went more than 5 minutes over nearly every single session. 
- I also did not enjoy cold calling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course would be a good fit for anyone who has any interest in Chinese or linguistics. You don't necessarily need a background in any of them to succeed, because Liu laoshi is willing to help you through it, but I think it helps in being able to understand the concepts faster. I only knew a little Chinese, and I had taken a linguistics course the semester before taking this class, and I think my linguistics knowledge made up for my Chinese knowledge. I think most other people in the class had a bit more background in Chinese but not as much in linguistics, so it depends. However, everyone was able to produce pretty successful research projects by the end of the semester, and there's a place for everyone's interests in the research project! I will say, the course can be a lot of reading at times, and the research project can be time-consuming depending on how you're collecting your data, so I would keep that in mind as you're balancing courses. My biggest takeaway from the course, though, is probably getting to learn more about my friends and their cultural experiences, so I would say that was worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take with friends, it's fun

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to analyze the methodology of studies that investigate the syntax of various speaker groups, and identify common errors in study design. I also learned more about the different tasks that can be used to assess syntax acquisition, such as truth value judgement tasks, and best practices for designing studies that use these tools effectively. Additionally, I learned about different language instruction theories and approaches, and how to integrate the insights thereof to most effectively teach language in the classroom.

response_text: Gained a deeper understanding of linguistic structures, phonetics, and cultural nuances unique to Korean, Chinese, and Japanese, helping me to discern similarities and differences among these languages. Specifically, I began to understand things that I never even knew to have existed; it was a unique kind of beauty to learn about these languages (Japanese, in particular) from an objective viewpoint, removed from "vibes" and intuitive instincts upon which I have consistently relied.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The focus on syntax and acquisition in this class is a bit rare at Duke, as I think that most of our linguistics classes are more sociolinguistics forward. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Interconnectedness: We partnered with the American University in Cairo, which offered unique and diverse perspectives.Historical Balance: We read from a range of texts from Western Historians, Middle-Eastern Historians, and Primary Texts.Zeitgeist through film: We "entered into" the times by watching films and documentaries from different relevant periods.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed knowledge about Cairo and Egypt more generally from ancient times to the 2010s, I learned how to ask critical questions about primary sources, and how to use primary and secondary sources to develop arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1-I learned how to read articles and come up with short opinion pieces based on my readings.
2-I learned a lot about the history of the city Cairo and more appropriately the history of Egypt as a country
3-I learned a lot about world history in general
4-I learned about how spacial control is implemented in certain cities through technological devices and certain infrastructure

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned about the founding of Cairo -- and how it began as a city in a completely different location!
2. Learned how to view a city's infrastructure as giving clues into its system of government or economic situation.
3. Learned how to constructively use primary sources to augment arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of Cairo from multiple perspectives: that of its history in a global context, the development of Cairo as an urban space, and the evolution of the city's public spaces and public sphere.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In-depth knowledge about the development and emergence of Cairo as a "city," a critical and comparative approach to defining what constitutes a "city" historically and spatially, and an introduction to scholarly discussions about the history of Cairo, Egypt, and the Middle East broadly (periodization, different approaches to primary sources, reconsidering/complicating the "colonial" moment/period, etc.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Having that additional background helped me make sense of the readings that were assigned for the week, and helped prepare me to understand the content for the day. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was structured to coincide and cooperate with a parallel class at the American University of Cairo. Regular virtual meetings featured authors whose work we read and discussed in class and discussions between students at Duke and AUC. It is rare to have the opportunity to pose questions about an assigned text to that text's author—that often ends up being the norm in Professor Mestyan's class.Professor Mestyan has an innovative approach to humanities and history education that treats students as serious thinkers and contributors. He reviews an array of analytical approaches in a simplified and accessible manner for undergraduate students while allowing the flexibility for students to maintain their own interpretations, provided they can defend their claims. The depth and complexity of assigned reading material could be relevant at a graduate, not just undergraduate, level. He is not only an expert in history and Middle Eastern/Egyptian history but an innovator in pedagogy and instruction in higher education. I would keep all components of this course for future years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course offered new ways of thinking about intimate geopolitics in the context of everyday life through the case studies we examined in Bosnia and Srebrenica to the genocide of Uyghurs in Xinjiang. This course combined rich, thought-provoking theoretical texts such as Edward Said's Orientalism, Jackson's concept of Black Orientalism, necropolitics, and biopolitics with case studies across the Muslim world. We problematized concepts such as islamophobia, jihad, and genocide as a class, which I found to be the most enriching element of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Each week we would look at a different case study or topic related to Islamophobia, including genocides in Bosnia and Xinjiang or the politics of veiling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A course that encompasses a breadth of material to critically interrogate what constitutes "story" and to whom. I learned about Eastern vs. Western storytelling modalities and the role of Orientalism in framing narratives in faraway lands through our unit on A Thousand and One Nights, as well as questioning if it is possible, in the guise of the modern novel with its emphasis on human consumption and emotion, to tell a story with a non-human subject by exploring the place of Sun Wu Kong in the Chinese literary canon. Turning our attention to familiar European storytelling traditions, we also studied the morphology of fairytales, as explicated by Vladimir Propp, and the socio-psychological imperatives baked into the archetypes of "fairy stories," as posited by Tolkien. We likewise explored the ways the framework of game changes narratives structures by imposing ludology, rather than temporality, to guide stories.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The central component of this class is to write nine essays centered around a storyworld of your choosing, fleshing out various aspects of the world to understand the cogs that make the machine of story function. These essays are a joy to write, as they are fueled by student interest, and they are also an essential tool for learning to apply the various methodologies and modalities gone over in lecture. Having these available as an open forum for everyone to look at each other's work promoted student engagement in our own storyworlds as well as close-readings of our peers, since we could comment and generate dialogue on each other's posts. Furthermore, class featured a mix of lecture and seminar-style engagement, which enabled us to wrangle with concepts for ourselves and develop our own nuanced opinions on how the art of worldbuilding and the various cultural heritages it draws upon can be done.

Dr. Chow's warm demeanor and razor-sharp intellect transform this class from an academic exercise to a veritable intellectual family.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Denis is fantastic! Not only is he incredibly knowledgeable, but he also brings a wealth of experience and insight to the class. His ability to connect theoretical concepts with real-world applications makes the material engaging and relevant. He encourages thoughtful discussions and challenges students to think critically, creating a stimulating and supportive learning environment. You will get a thorough understanding of China's science and technology policies, focusing on real-world challenges and innovations. The multidisciplinary approach helps you connect political economy, technology, and global relations. With rich case studies, interactive discussions, and high-quality readings, it fosters critical thinking and practical knowledge. This course is perfect for students interested in global innovation dynamics, China's technological rise, or the intersection of policy and science. And, Professor Simon is definitely the one to guide you through this complex and fascinating subject. His passion for the topic and dedication to his students make the learning experience truly exceptional. If you want to gain a deep understanding of China's innovation strategies and their global impact, this course, led by Professor Denis Simon, is an opportunity you shouldn’t miss.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is designed specifically for students who are interested in East Asian popular culture and feminism. If you are an active East Asian popular culture/subculture consumer or participant, or you have a lot to say about the ongoing feminist movements in East Asia, you should find the course very inspiring and interesting. But sometimes the topics can be very specifically linked to a certain type of popular culture, so if you are not familiar with it enough, you might not be able to truly immerse yourself in the intellectual conversation in class. Also, most attention is paid to Chinese or Chinese-related materials. The course is not that reading-intensive and neither does it involve much training on theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, I developed critical understanding of the context and imperatives of East Asian Studies. The question of what it means to be an Asian Asianist allowed me to deeply engage with our reading materials and speakers from various academic and disciplinary backgrounds. Secondly, I developed writing skills on generalizing and discussing about the arguments made by our speakers. Thirdly, I was able to reflect on the possibilities and limitations of my own discipline and at the same time bridging conversation with other disciplines.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learned a great deal about the "secrets of academia." Professor Chow meticulously introduces disciplines and methodologies by inviting professors from different fields each week, a valuable experience not easily found elsewhere. Through interactions with these professors, I've grasped the subtle nuances between disciplines, topics, academic institutions, and departments. This understanding will be immensely helpful for my future doctoral applications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The history of East Asian Studies; New theories and trends in Asian history;  New theories and trends in Asian literature

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Professor Ara Wilson's concept of queer regionalism is especially insightful, as it negotiates the dominant Western queer studies with cultural contexts in East Asian society. 2. Professor Qiao's illustrations on the Homeowner Associations in China shows how grassroots organizations not only function hand in hand with the state power but also grant a degree of agency for ordinary people. 3. I've been intrigued by the approach that views Asia as a method instead of the object of study, which stresses cross-regional culture flow and Asia's cultural specificity as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Reading Kuan-hsing Chen's work allowed me to perceive how scholars think about what it means to be an Asian Asianist and what Asia, as a construction, can reflect on itself and can provide to the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

The significant works Professor Rojas discussed not only represent critical gateways but also serve as core focal points within East Asian research. Understanding these essential works in each of these areas has laid a strong foundation for me, shaping my academic paradigm. Professor Rojas also dedicates specific class time to teach writing skills, fostering mutual learning among students. Every essay receives meticulous feedback, which has been incredibly beneficial for me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Out of all the courses I've taken in my four years at this school, this one has helped me the most, especially in developing my critical thinking and writing skills. It taught me how to draw meaningful connections across various forms of media, from movies and books to short stories and anime. One specific thing I’ve learned is how to think critically in ways I hadn’t before. Now, when I read a book or watch a movie, I find myself looking for deeper connections. Discussing these ideas in class with my peers has also opened me up to new perspectives, helping me understand the text or media in ways I wouldn’t have on my own. I also became a better writer, being able to incorporate multiple resources, and flesh out strong arguments that I can write a paper about. And I now have a very strong understanding of the meaning of "the post apocalypse".

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Koo structured the course in a way that balanced thematic progression with skill development. Weekly paragraphs encouraged consistent engagement, while short essays scaffolded our final paper. Her clear prompts, regular check-ins, and individualized support—especially during office hours and workshops—made a huge difference. The flexibility to explore our interests (e.g., choosing our own topics/texts for essays) fostered genuine curiosity and intellectual risk-taking. I would keep the "Paragraph of the Week" assignments and the final paper workshops.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Transnational spreading of Confucianism, ethnographical methodologies, religious factors and evaluations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've read about various insightful interpretations of Confucian classics and the relationship between traditional Confucian values and contemporary societies. Specifically, I'm especially impressed by the perspective of viewing Confucianism as a religion, which entails a very novel and persuasive definition of the term religion itself. I've also encountered many Confucian ritual practices which I've been familiar with in my past life, and gained completely new understandings of these rituals, especially ancestral worships. Third, I've been intrigued by a recent reading material discussing the "as-if" world created by ritual practices, with an emphasis on the gap between the Confucian ideal and the reality.

I think this course really emphasized multiple ways of thinking, beyond just the subject matter (Tokyo) itself

- A lot of this course focused on comparing visual media sources, and understanding their implications and can be applied in a very broad context
2. Urban Studies
- This course really nailed the various factors that make up any urban environment, and how they connect (such as social, economic and political)
3. Art Historical Analysis
- We had a lot of time focused on engaging in classic art historical analysis on various materials

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed several valuable ways of thinking and analysis. First, I was introduced to foundational game theories that helped me understand how systems of rules, play, and interaction can be used to critique and reimagine social dynamics. Second, I strengthened my analytical mindset by learning to draw connections between diverse readings, case studies, and media, bringing together theory and practice in meaningful ways during discussion. Finally, I began to see technology not just as a tool but as a medium that shapes how we understand identity and selfhood, especially through immersive experiences like games, virtual realities, and interactive media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
skills: analytical writing/thinking, group discourse, note taking, reading and interpreting different types of sources
knowledge: learned about the history of the Israel/Palestine conflict, the different actors involved in the region over time, how to think about the issue from different perspectives, and how to think about new frameworks toward peace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading and skimming through a lot of content in a short amount of time, knowledge gathering skills, critical thinking and analysis of texts. Exam preparation skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we learned to examine history through a personal lens by analyzing memoirs and primary sources from varying perspectives. We also learned to engage in texts by completing weekly reading responses. Lastly, we learned to pull out thematic patterns and common threads over the course of Israeli-Palestinian history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me so much more context to understand the situation in Israel-Palestine and helped me to develop the skills to approach understanding longstanding conflict. Learning to think about how to make compromises between groups with so much animosity was incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach the Israeli-Palestinian conflict with numerous perspectives. I learned how to write critically and analyze readings. I also learned the deep history of the conflict which I didn't know existed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I left the class with my analytical writing skills much better than they were previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

response_text: The overall structure of the class was pretty clear and cohesive, only thing I would change is make the lectures more relevant to the reading material and make it easier to follow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the lecture style of the class. With an issue as complicated and politically relevant as this one, I think keeping this course predominantly lecture style was really important. It created a standardized base of knowledge that we all could access and understand. I also think the amount of guest speakers we were able to have was truly incredible.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the readings were a very appropriate amount of context for the lectures, and that the course did a good job generally in trying not to tackle too much with such a limited amount of time. The opportunity to speak to guest speakers was incredibly interesting as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the way they taught the class! It was very interactive and made me pay attention. They had speakers a lot which was very cool and nice to switch things up.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would definitely continue using films, clips, and media to teach.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class approaches one of the most hateful conflicts in the world at a time when it is possibly at its worst ever. I have thought deeply about topics we discuss in class in my free time and found myself trying to read more as the conflict continues to unfold. Readings in this class moved me to tears on multiple occasions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The speakers and passionate lessons by the teachers made this class stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really enjoyed the array of disciplines we used to analyze themes in the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The instructors took significant time to engage with the students, answering our questions and asking many of us rather than just lecturing.  I thought it was an excellent balance of instruction and discussion.  I also really enjoyed the guest speakers that we had-- we had the honor of speaking to so many people who were leading expets in the field or were directly affected by the conflict.  We were able to engage with them directly and ask them questions about their work, which added new dimension to the topics we were studying.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a course I think everyone should take. It gives you the language and historical context to understand a particularly fraught political moment. If you show up, are an active participant, and pay attention, anyone can do well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class, especially if you feel a deep connection to either side of the conflict. This class will challenge your viewpoints either way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this if you have an open mind about the conflict and want to learn more!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should absolutely sign up for this course.  Dr. Weinthal and Dr. Stein are tremendous teachers who help break down the complexity of the Israel/Palestine conflict without ever minimizing the difficulties of it.  The class will teach you so much about human rights, natural resources, state-building, and the history of one of the most visible global conflicts.  You won't just learn about what happened, you will be asked to engage directly with thehuman dimensions of this conflict and confront the difficult realities of the past and current situation.  This class is a must take.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

This class is a must take.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Ralph Litzinger is the most admirable and appreciated teacher I have encountered at Duke. His courses are rich, profound, and thought-provoking, showcasing his passion and dedication to teaching in every session. Beyond the classroom, Professor Litzinger genuinely cares about his students' growth and development. During moments when I felt lost and uncertain, his support and encouragement helped me regain my motivation and confidence. His guidance has not only advanced my academic journey but also brought me courage and strength in life. Being his student is one of the most treasured experiences of my time at Duke, and his influence will forever remain in my memory. Professor Ralph Litzinger is truly an irreplaceable mentor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Denis is fantastic! Not only is he incredibly knowledgeable, but he also brings a wealth of experience and insight to the class. His ability to connect theoretical concepts with real-world applications makes the material engaging and relevant. He encourages thoughtful discussions and challenges students to think critically, creating a stimulating and supportive learning environment. You will get a thorough understanding of China's science and technology policies, focusing on real-world challenges and innovations. The multidisciplinary approach helps you connect political economy, technology, and global relations. With rich case studies, interactive discussions, and high-quality readings, it fosters critical thinking and practical knowledge. This course is perfect for students interested in global innovation dynamics, China's technological rise, or the intersection of policy and science. And, Professor Simon is definitely the one to guide you through this complex and fascinating subject. His passion for the topic and dedication to his students make the learning experience truly exceptional. If you want to gain a deep understanding of China's innovation strategies and their global impact, this course, led by Professor Denis Simon, is an opportunity you shouldn’t miss.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, I developed critical understanding of the context and imperatives of East Asian Studies. The question of what it means to be an Asian Asianist allowed me to deeply engage with our reading materials and speakers from various academic and disciplinary backgrounds. Secondly, I developed writing skills on generalizing and discussing about the arguments made by our speakers. Thirdly, I was able to reflect on the possibilities and limitations of my own discipline and at the same time bridging conversation with other disciplines.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learned a great deal about the "secrets of academia." Professor Chow meticulously introduces disciplines and methodologies by inviting professors from different fields each week, a valuable experience not easily found elsewhere. Through interactions with these professors, I've grasped the subtle nuances between disciplines, topics, academic institutions, and departments. This understanding will be immensely helpful for my future doctoral applications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Professor Ara Wilson's concept of queer regionalism is especially insightful, as it negotiates the dominant Western queer studies with cultural contexts in East Asian society. 2. Professor Qiao's illustrations on the Homeowner Associations in China shows how grassroots organizations not only function hand in hand with the state power but also grant a degree of agency for ordinary people. 3. I've been intrigued by the approach that views Asia as a method instead of the object of study, which stresses cross-regional culture flow and Asia's cultural specificity as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I developed a critical understanding of how the Pacific is imagined beyond geographic borders—through lenses like trauma, techno-orientalism, environmental collapse, and posthumanism.
-I strengthened my ability to closely read and interpret film and literature through weekly paragraph reflections and analytical essays. This course helped me shift from surface-level observation to deep cultural critique.
-I learned to conduct archival and secondary research for literary analysis, particularly through our Rubenstein Library visit and the library session on sourcing academic criticism for our final paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My media literacy definitely improved greatly. I also learned a lot about engaging actively in discussion about media and literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analysis of the post-apocalypse in Asian-American literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the Pacific Ocean through history and post-apocalyptic fiction. I engaged with impressive and mind expanding media I would not have otherwise encountered and challenged my perspectives on things I was already familar with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really pushed my critical thinking and textual analysis skills. We analyzed films and texts that I would not have thought to analyze on my own, and it really allowed me to see how these skills in analysis I am developing can be applied to a range of media. This course also reframed my understanding of anime, sci-fi, and fiction. It was really interesting examining primary texts and films that I have watched for fun in a different way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe that this course was very valuable in helping develop as both a writer and in analysis of a variety of media forms. I became more able to synthesize ideas about texts into conversation to more deeply engage with symbols, themes and character concepts, developed in creating arguable theses for papers, and also have gained important research skills relating to secondary sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to examine films through a symbolic and literary lens. I also learned how to close read novels/long prose to identify symbolism and deeper meanings beneath the text. Finally, I would say the most important skill I learned was learning to write using new theories and ideas that we went over and integrating those into my own writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Out of all the courses I've taken in my four years at this school, this one has helped me the most, especially in developing my critical thinking and writing skills. It taught me how to draw meaningful connections across various forms of media, from movies and books to short stories and anime. One specific thing I’ve learned is how to think critically in ways I hadn’t before. Now, when I read a book or watch a movie, I find myself looking for deeper connections. Discussing these ideas in class with my peers has also opened me up to new perspectives, helping me understand the text or media in ways I wouldn’t have on my own. I also became a better writer, being able to incorporate multiple resources, and flesh out strong arguments that I can write a paper about. And I now have a very strong understanding of the meaning of "the post apocalypse".

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Koo structured the course in a way that balanced thematic progression with skill development. Weekly paragraphs encouraged consistent engagement, while short essays scaffolded our final paper. Her clear prompts, regular check-ins, and individualized support—especially during office hours and workshops—made a huge difference. The flexibility to explore our interests (e.g., choosing our own topics/texts for essays) fostered genuine curiosity and intellectual risk-taking. I would keep the "Paragraph of the Week" assignments and the final paper workshops.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a broad understanding of the Middle East and a view into the history of the region. I learnt to understand current events within the historical context

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how the World Wars shaped the development of states in the Middle East
2) I learned, through Dr. Gemeah's personal accounts of the Arab Spring and watching Operation Iraqi Freedom on television, how people native to the region interpreted US involvement post-9/11
3) I learned about state secularization efforts in Iran and Turkey and how the two regions had similar motivations but vastly different outcomes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Gained basic understanding of the development of the Middle East as a region and major historic forces behind it. Was introduced to a variety of primary sources and learned to engage with them. Improved my skills of source analysis and historical writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of knowledge of the early history of the Middle East (ie. Ottoman Empire), and how this period connects to modern history. I also learned how to critically analyze primary sources, especially films, and how to accurately use these sources in a paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I developed more skills in finding and understanding both sides of a perspective, as well as just knowing more about how visual and written primary sources are equally as helpful in understanding history. Additionally, I think I gained more insight into the US' role in the Middle East and how it is often not as it is presented to the American public.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course greatly enhanced my critical thinking and my ability to draw connections between seemingly disparate historical events and trends. My understanding of the US's relationship with the Middle East grew tremendously and this course expanded my capacity for empathy in thinking about certain political movements that I previously disagreed with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I have taken a lot of history courses that focus on ancient history, so taking one that extended to the modern day gave me a really complete picture of how exactly the modern situations have been created.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much more about ancient and early modern Japanese history. I also learned more about analyzing primary documents and how to effectively discuss them and synthesize them with secondary sources.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: It was interesting learning about the history of Japan. I think the biggest skill I took away from this experience was critical thinking, as in understanding the complexities of historical documentation. I also learned how to pick apart a text from a historical narrative. I think that in other classes it's more geared toward understanding an essence, and while it still holds for historical documents, you also need to immerse yourself in the time the event occurred to truly understand it. I also broaden my way of thinking, which I think has become more fluid and less rigid because of the course.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about all aspects of ancient Japanese culture. I went into this course knowing literally nothing about Japan and I came out of it with a pretty good understanding of the development of their society.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The way of thinking I developed during this course was unique to other classes. I learned that to understand history you have to understand there are different perspectives and that not everything is black and white. As an example, although women faced massive amounts of discrimination throughout ancient Japanese history there are extraordinary examples of women being leaders, writers, and equals in society. Three specific things I learned was different art forms (Nō, Kabuki, etc), societal systems, and the relationships Japan had with outside states (Korea, China, Netherlands etc)

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The varied materials and class activities facilitated my learning. Between discussions, mock debates, lectures, and readings, there were many opportunities for different kinds of learning. I liked the in class discussions, when the professor would ask us about what we thought of the readings. My favorite readings were excerpts from literature like Five Women Who Loved Love and the Pillow Book.

course: HISTORY-226-01 : ANCIENT AND EARLY MODERN JAPAN.HISTORY-226-01.AMES-167-01.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Interconnectedness: We partnered with the American University in Cairo, which offered unique and diverse perspectives.Historical Balance: We read from a range of texts from Western Historians, Middle-Eastern Historians, and Primary Texts.Zeitgeist through film: We "entered into" the times by watching films and documentaries from different relevant periods.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed knowledge about Cairo and Egypt more generally from ancient times to the 2010s, I learned how to ask critical questions about primary sources, and how to use primary and secondary sources to develop arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1-I learned how to read articles and come up with short opinion pieces based on my readings.
2-I learned a lot about the history of the city Cairo and more appropriately the history of Egypt as a country
3-I learned a lot about world history in general
4-I learned about how spacial control is implemented in certain cities through technological devices and certain infrastructure

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned about the founding of Cairo -- and how it began as a city in a completely different location!
2. Learned how to view a city's infrastructure as giving clues into its system of government or economic situation.
3. Learned how to constructively use primary sources to augment arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of Cairo from multiple perspectives: that of its history in a global context, the development of Cairo as an urban space, and the evolution of the city's public spaces and public sphere.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In-depth knowledge about the development and emergence of Cairo as a "city," a critical and comparative approach to defining what constitutes a "city" historically and spatially, and an introduction to scholarly discussions about the history of Cairo, Egypt, and the Middle East broadly (periodization, different approaches to primary sources, reconsidering/complicating the "colonial" moment/period, etc.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Too much Lecture; almost zero discussion. We read from an array of professionals in the field, but any attempt to drive dialogue in the class seems to be a "distraction" from the instructor's prepared remarks. I trust this works for some, but this didn't lend itself to my better retaining much of the information.Too rarely did we introduce a "so what?" within any of the material. Much of the information seemed to be "nice to know" information, rather than meaningfully contributing to academic use of the new information.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course professor did a fantastic job of keeping us engaged throughout the entire lecture -- it was particularly informative learning about the history of Cairo and current issues it grapples with today by hearing from professors and experts located in Cairo -- I really loved the Zooms we did in conjunction with AUC!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the professor started each lecture with some global context before diving into the main topic for the day. Having that additional background helped me make sense of the readings that were assigned for the week, and helped prepare me to understand the content for the day. I also liked the format of the major assignments: one midterm essay, a presentation, and one final paper. It was manageable but effective.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was structured to coincide and cooperate with a parallel class at the American University of Cairo. Regular virtual meetings featured authors whose work we read and discussed in class and discussions between students at Duke and AUC. It is rare to have the opportunity to pose questions about an assigned text to that text's author—that often ends up being the norm in Professor Mestyan's class.Professor Mestyan has an innovative approach to humanities and history education that treats students as serious thinkers and contributors. He reviews an array of analytical approaches in a simplified and accessible manner for undergraduate students while allowing the flexibility for students to maintain their own interpretations, provided they can defend their claims. The depth and complexity of assigned reading material could be relevant at a graduate, not just undergraduate, level. He is not only an expert in history and Middle Eastern/Egyptian history but an innovator in pedagogy and instruction in higher education. I would keep all components of this course for future years.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: In short, please avoid Saito! No matter how you love Japanese culture and people, she will ruin it!Here is the complete story:Saito is the most mean, annoying, and old-school person I have ever met at Duke. She is bad at teaching but good at making troubles. I believe you might have heard that this is a challenging class. I have taken some of the most challenging STEM classes at Duke. But I feel I learned a lot from suffering in these classes.HOWEVER, the suffering she makes you feel is meaningless. Completely meaningless. Throughout the semester, she will find you a lot of troubles and she is zero-tolerant to any mistakes you made. She never attempts to empathize with your life and what you experience. She is only a MACHINE, a cold machine, to enforce rules.Ok, you might not be a picky person about who teach the class. But in her class, you will not succeed by grinding before exams. The exams only contribute a small percent to your grade. Basically, this class will DOMINATE your life. You have to be constantly hardworking to succeed. Imagine, college can be stressful, well, most of the time. You don’t want to add another layer of misery to your life, trust me.

response_text: I appreciate how Zeena diversified our classroom activities. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The work that was done with Derrida and deconstruction helped me to develop greater critical thinking skills as it broadened my mindset and consider how the definitions and norms that we think of today can be reconstructed or questioned based on their rationale and validity. Our time on Kant and Mahmood has helped me to consider the role that ethics might truly play. Most poignantly, the idea that American ethics in doing no harm is not truly virtue. Instead, considering how I might reconsider my own decisions and everyday life in the pursuit of cultivating virtue. Finally, Althusser and Foucault have allowed me to question the origins of the various norms that I take for granted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was awesome! Emily's enthusiasm for the class and the material is evident and contagious. She was an incredibly approachable, flexible, and caring professor and created an environment where it felt like we were really able to think critically while also having fun in a low-stakes environment. The course's selected topics and the sequence in which these topics were presented were logical and coherent. I appreciated that Emily took the time to contextualize each new topic we discussed within the scope of what we had learned thus far. Topics were well-connected and referenced each other, which gave me a deeper appreciation for the course's ethnomusicological lens and each of the individual musics. Emily did a fantastic job of fostering a friendly and supportive class environment. Despite the larger class size, it felt like we were able to have discussions, share ideas, and get to know each other's ways of thinking. Emily also seemed genuinely interested in learning from us, fostering a non-hierarchical classroom environment (versus one where the professor clearly presents as the all-knowing expert uninterested in students' insights) that I think greatly encouraged students' independent thinking. Karaoke was a lot of fun and also helped build camaraderie among the class. I think all of the assignments were meaningful and useful while also leaving plenty of room for our own thinking and creativity (e.g. 3 you pick listening journals and a very open-ended final project). Course assignments were structured in a way that leaves options and appeals to a diversity of strengths and weaknesses (e.g. appealing to those who prefer test-taking vs. essay-writing and to those who prefer independent vs group work). Most of all, this class was fun! It's such a relief to have a class that is genuinely fun, where the professor is also excited to just have fun while still learning a lot.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
