question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take, even if you don't know Chinese language or culture because you don't need to at all. It is just a philosophy course, and an amazing one at that. Engaging in philosophy has been such a beneficial experience for me, and frankly I think a philosophy course ought to be required for every student, especially considering the course requirement changes being made.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it. IF you understand something, five pages should be enough to talk about it to an informed reader.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I'd recommend for those who want to engage with the content, most of it is going to be from internal reflection and consideration and some from class discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Argumentative writing skills were strongly developed in this course. Professor Schanzer does not like any fluff in his writing. Through this class you learn how to make sure every sentence forwards your argument.Thinking through an argument. In class, even if Schanzer likes your idea, he's going to push back. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to think critically about how decisions that were made in the best interest of the United States in the moment of terror have rippling effects on much of our politics today. I learned about the different presidential administrations and their responses to the "War on Terror" and how the framing of war has an impact on outcomes. I also learned about the history of Afghanistan and the Middle East, which I had previously been unfamiliar with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class forced me to think critically about how difficult foreign policy can be. It helped me to understand the last two decades of U.S. intervention abroad in the context of 9/11. I have come to see 9/11 not just as a tragic isolated event, but rather the beginning of a new era of American politics: the War on Terror did not end with our withdrawal from Iraq, it just wears a different hat now.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Schanzer did an incredible job of asking good questions and pushing back on student reponses in class. He always had a way of questioning what we said, almost making us second guess ourselves, but in a productive way in which we could consider counterarguments we may not have considered before.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Schanzer was amazing - I would take 10 more classes with him. He is so smart and I love the way he pushes on students. Even though I was more timid to speak up in the large class, I felt fully engaged. He really knows how to make your brain hurt and make you think. I found the class readings (although often very long) always interesting, relevant, and worth reading. I loved how readings helped us see the issues from both sides. I also really enjoyed the smaller discussion sections - they helped me feel more comfortable to voice my thoughts. The blog posts were also really helpful. It was all great basically!!!!!!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was almost entirely discussion based. I think it used to be smaller in size, but even with more students, the debates were always lively and engaging. Schanzer asked sharp, thought-provoking questions and assigned readings, videos, and podcasts that were consistently insightful. As I mentioned earlier, he had a unique ability to push back on every point, encouraging us to think more critically. He remained bipartisan throughout, always prepared with arguments from multiple sides, which helped us develop a well-rounded understanding of the material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This is an outstanding class primarily because it is discussion-based. With such difficult topics, students can really only figure out their opinions and stances through hearing others present theirs and then revise/alter their own accordingly to share with the class. The discussion posts, due before class, help make sure that everyone is entering discussions prepared enough to raise their hand and contribute something to the class, even if they hadn't completed every assigned reading. The papers were spaced out very well and never felt like a disproportionately long, complex, or difficult task.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: David Schanzer is an amazing professor. He cares so much about what he teaches and his students as well, I loved the way he facilitated group discussions. I enjoyed the readings and the weekly blog posts. I also loved the small group discussions with Ken/Schanzer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: i liked how we broke into discussion groups to talk about topics more thoroughly and in smaller groups, it gave me an opportunity to understand the content more. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The way that our discussions were held in both the large class and smaller sections was excellent. Professor Schanzer did a phenomenal job of ensuring everyone had a chance to clearly articulate their thoughts, and would offer counterarguments that would require us to dig deeper. None of the discussions we had were ever superficial, and many times I left the class with my brain aching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated my learning by pushing me and my classmates to consider the other side of the argument and go further with our analysis of a topic. He always asked tricky follow up questions which encouraged us to think deeply about the topics and get to the core of the problem. Moreover, with rewrites I was able to learn/understand what I did wrong and work to improve my work—ultimately strengthening my argumentative writing skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Discussion posts, course materials, and class discussions made sure I was regularly engaged and keeping up with the course as it progressed. I enjoyed having to be a debater and a responder respectively, and the reflection essays were helpful in forcing myself to dive deeper into the content and consider my classmates' perspectives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was conversation based. The professor would ask a question and then discussion would kick off after that. I think the types of questions asked allowed for the conversation to flow. I enjoyed that it was purely discussion based.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the weekly blogs, because it forced me to consider the readings more thoroughly than if the only homework was to just read them. I also like the discussion sections.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Schanzer is an incredible professor and any class he teaches will push you to be a better thinker, writer, and human. I really enjoyed the blog components as it gave us a chance to share thoughts and perspectives in a less stressful environment as opposed to sharing out in class which can sometimes be daunting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Schanzer is an incredible teacher, not just because he is beyond knowledgeable about this topic, but also because he pushes his students to be better, in every sense of the word. I really appreciated how he goes out of his way to facilitate meaningful discussion inside (and outside of class). Instead of just asking discussion questions in class he encourages us to dig deeper by challenging the points we make. For our midterm assignments we are provided with copious amounts of helpful feedback that we and then encouraged to use when revising out essays. This process has made me a better writer and challenged me to put more thought and care into my written assignments. Above all things academic I truly believe that Professor Schanzer cares deeply about his students success and well being. He is always willing to meet outside of class and take great care to get to know his students. Overall Professor Schanzer is a great teacher and he teaches a great course!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The purely discussion based nature of this class based on readings that we did outside of class made it so my learning was compounded. Professor Schanzer would start each class with a question that would lead to the remaining time being spent in discussion with students building off of each others' ideas or disagreeing with points made. The way that everyone was encouraged to share their reactions/ideas based on the readings made it so I would come in to class thinking one way, and always leave class with new ideas about different policies, military actions, presidential decisions, etc.. I would definitely keep the discussion sections in following years, and maybe even reverting back to a smaller class size to encourage participation. Having Ken was super helpful too in having someone present that was actually in Afghanistan/Iraq and could speak on the military aspects of the conflicts before and after 9/11. Having a CTTP fellow next year with a similar background would be great. Also I really liked how we went in chronological order all the way back thousands of years, at first I was confused what Sayyid Qutb would have to do with 9/11 all the way back in the 1930s, but then it all made sense.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Schanzer was challenging but in a very constructive way. He made it clear that he held us to high standards in our writing and classroom discussions, so we felt pushed to put in our best work. Therefore, my engagement in this class was higher than usual, as I knew I would be challenged and wanted to succeed/meet Schanzer's approval. Schanzer is also very skilled at facilitating discussions, prompting and challenging our opinions and forcing us to think more deeply about complicated issues.I also really liked the structure and flow of the course and how we zoomed in on different topics--contemporary or historical--while also maintaining a broad understanding of the necessary background info, i.e., the history of Muslim civilization. My favorite topic we zoomed in on was probably the Israel Palestine discussion. I did not have much to add personally that day since I did not have much background info, but I really benefitted from hearing what my classmates with differing opinions had to say, as well as Schanzer's insight. I also liked the homegrown terrorism and TSA/airport discussions a lot, as my classmates and I had a lot of differing views and personal experiences with these topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the flipped classroom format, it provided us with the ability to have rich conversations in class, with a range of perspectives. I really like how Prof. Schanzer challenged us, he would respond to our thoughts and provoke us to think deeper. I don't think he should change anything about the format though I wish the class was 15 people smaller

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought the course material and essays were extremely stimulating. However, I felt class discussions were sometimes boring. Sometimes the professor would pick what I thought to be dull areas to probe (I.e. the legality of something as opposed to whether it was right strategically or ethically). My primary qualm, however, is how he responds to points you make in class. He routinely picks to respond to what was a minor point of what you were saying and launch into a rant about something and often lose the audience. I like how he pushes people on their responses, but I wish he wouldn't respond with long rants

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The range of topics that we covered relating to 9/11 made the class very stimulating. I also really enjoyed that we were able to read things from people with opposing views on the same topic.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: class was interesting, blog posts not as much. specifically, refine the readings but expect everyone to do them. spend more time on Iraq and Afghanistan, and then the discussions will be more informed/interesting. this extra refining will limit the content covered but i think that is a worthy trade

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The classroom discussions forced me to see new perspectives and evaluate arguments made by classmates. I would have preferred periods of smaller group discussion, where classmates would be sectioned off into smaller groups and discuss in that type of environment.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked that each class was a discussion, and that we were asked follow up questions based on what we said. I felt interested in everyone else's perspective and was always sure to have an interesting, fully fleshed out thought before sharing with the group.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As mentioned above the way Professor Schanzer asks follow up questions is very good and challenges us to think quickly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it challenged me to question dominant national security narratives and explore the ethical and political consequences of U.S. counterterrorism strategies. The mix of historical analysis, political theory, and real-world case studies made every discussion relevant and thought-provoking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: At the end of most classes my "brain hurt" because professor Schanzer pushed me to consider a new point of view or go a step further in my reasoning, posing challenging questions with no clear answers. However tehse questions pushed me as a student to consider a new perspective and strengthen my understanding of a topic.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class covered an incredibly wide breadth of history very comprehensively. It was thoughtfully arranged and it's obvious that Professor Schanzer is an expert in the field. I would've hoped to dive deeper into the legal/ ethical implications of certain issues rather than focusing primarily on strategy and security.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The way the professor played devils advocate to everyone really helped challenge my own way of thinking. I also enjoyed the variety of readings that challenged what I thought I already knew about 9/11. I do think that this class is begging for a small group component. It is hard to try to speak up in this class, it is an intimidating environment. Breaking up into small groups for like 20 minutes with a question or 2 for the groups to discuss and then report out to the class could be extremely valuable and allow everyone to share in a more comfortable environment.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: All in all the course was incredible although it could be quite challenging at times. The feedback and construction that is given by both Schanzer and the TAs is honestly invaluable and something I will think about for probably the rest of my Duke career.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The content was fascinating and the structure of the course encouraged critical thinking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The class was stimulating because the material itself has been very contested over the years. Especially because policy is inherently political; therefore, we usually were dealing with topics that had at least two sides. Professor Schanzer pushed back on everyone, no matter what side they were taking, encouraging to consider things from another perspective. He would always respond to our points with "what about when this happened..." or "so you're saying..." and it always made us think more about what we said in the context of things we might not have considered in our conclusions. I think the discussion sections were especially good for this because I got to hear more people speak in a more intimate environment, which always helped challenge my thoughts even when it wasn't Prof Schanzer/Ken directly asking me follow up questions. 
Also rewrites are an awesome opportunity to get critical feedback and rework some of our ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The rich discussion and interesting lectures were very stimulating. I liked the readings as well, especially when we were assigned videos/documentary-like explanations of topics as I am a visual learner. It was very cool when we were given specific, more personal anecdotes to read/watch as those are extra engaging, i.e., the video on terrorist recruitment. Whenever Ken shared his personal experiences with class topics was also fascinating. I already mentioned really liking the flow of the course topics, but Schanzer was really good at laying everything out for us in a very structured way that was helpful for me to visualize.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was extremely stimulating, the content of the class was so interesting and it all felt extremely timely and I think Professor Schanzer did a great job compiling a range of materials, so we could form our perspective with all the facts

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of reading but do not let that intimidate you. Professor Schanzer goes out of his way to make relationships with his students—even hosting a group dinner at the end of the course. This is a course that will challenge you and force you to think about the topics outside of the classroom.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
This class is a large workload and you have to do the readings. It means that you will be incredibly knowledgeable about 9/11 afterwards, but oftentimes I was overwhelmed and stressed by the sheer amount of work I had to do and the difficulty in formulating responses to essays. Professor Schanzer will not sugarcoat his feedback, which is very helpful, but also means that sometimes essay feedback can feel a little disheartening. 
If you're interested in national security and American foreign policy, I highly recommend this course. If you would like to analyze America's response to 9/11 through a more progressive, human rights centric lens, this course does not delve deep into that topic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this class is really interesting and is not too time consuming. I learned a lot and would recommend it to someone who is interested in learning about scripture!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Pay attention in class because your professors are experts in their fields. Start your essays early.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: it was engaging, i recommend you to take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Engage with it the best you can! If you do it could be one of the most interesting and fun classes you'll take in your time at Duke. I think it's important to learn the history of our world and a great way to do so is through learning about religion and how it impacted previous lives and continues to impact lives to this day. I can't emphasize enough to engage with the readings and participate in the lecures. Keep an open mind and use it to engage with all three religions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class appears to be nitty gritty and a deep dive into scripture. It is, but it is so important to understand these nuances as you enter the world. It has enabled me to have educated discussions about world events. TAKE IT!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a pretty easy class if you need trinity requirements or need it for a minor. It's just a lot of reading, and you have 2 papers but no quizzes, tests, or final.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't do the readings. They suck and don't help you understand the course at all. Skim whatever you need to finish the reading assignments. Go to every lecture, even if you don't pay attention. On the papers, talk with the professors often. They will give you good advice and direction.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very different than the traditional class you will take at Duke. Professors really prioritize learning rather than testtaking.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is definitely interesting and you'll learn a lot just prepare to read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: my favorite new skill/insight is the ability to read scripture with a historical-critical eye

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze and think critically about scripture and other pieces of media related to scripture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really enjoyed and learned a lot from the readings, assignments, and lectures. I learned a lot about the interpretations of scripture and the scripture itself.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I finished with a better understanding on how I should write my class reflections.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Scripture is interpretive. Reading with the lens of context and willingness to adapt perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: all about scripture and where it came from

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify different sections on pages of the Qur'an, supposed discrepancies in the Bible, and the discourse surrounding the interpretation of "slave" or "servant" in the Bible.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze texts and apply them across different cultures. I learned how to write well thought through research papers. I learned how to engage with different opinions than my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about Islamic religion and culture I never knew before, such as how Muslims greatly differed in their style of interpretation of scripture and how their scripture was revealed; I learned about how there is no such thing as a single scripture or a shared belief because religion changes constantly and is constantly interpreted; I learned that each Abrahamic faith has a specific tradition of interpretation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how complex religion and scripture is 
- the importance of understanding the limitations of scripture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. Learning about the three different major monotheistic religions is learning three specific things in and of themselves. Learning about religion in a historical context is one of the most interesting things to learn and I've learned to shift my thinking from a theological prespective to a historical critical one. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the evolution of the three main Abrahamic texts. I learned how scripture is interpreted, who interprets it, and how that has shaped the communities of different religions. I learned how to be a historic critic of religious texts and why that role is ESSENTIAL to understanding society and religion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how scriptures of Islam, Christianity, and Judaism are compiled and interpreted. I also learned about the basic structure of each religious text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Reading scripture as "a book" rather than a religious text
Learned different methods of interpretation
learned the history that led to the evolution of these different interpretations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at scriptures from a historical and critical perspective rather than a religious one
I learned about the canonization of each scripture and the complexities behind each
I learned of how each of the religions cope with issues and how they try to modernize

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to distinguish between religion and scripture from a scholarly perspective. We learned different words in Greek, Hebrew, and Arabic. We also learned about different key figures in each religious tradition.

response_text: the structure of choosing a focus and then working through it in each tradition was well laid out (much better than doing the 1st portion strictly on judaism, the middle portion on christianity, and the final portion on islam)

response_text: I appreciate that the class was very organized, however, the format of every class being solely comprised of lecture was not the most engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors were very open to answering questions outside of class and were very quick to respond which I appreciated. Each professor was so excited to speak about their areas which was nice to see.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the lectures, they were very stimulating. I also thought the readings were interesting and actually pertinent. I also liked visiting the rare books library and attending the Iftar. More experiences like that during the course or as supplements would be really interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the reading to help facilitate learning in lectures and I also appreciated that we had a guided reflection to fill out about the readings. It held me accountable to do my readings and engage with them. I also just enjoyed the overall structure of the class and how it would shift from each religion and how there would aslo be days where our professors would teach on a common topic. Additional to the structure I enjoyed that there were only two major assignments to do throughout the whole semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were "good" for the most part. It's definitely the right idea, but sometimes the instructions were vague and the links were hard to find. I would certainly keep these graded readings, and expand on the feedback. The lectures were always excellent and the professors always came OVERLY prepared. It was impressive and refreshing to be taught by professors who had too many slides and could talk for hours on their subject. Don't change a thing about the lectures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors would often give us handouts to follow along easier in class, and they also would pick students to read slides, which was helpful in keeping us engaged. The reading responses  also helped us come into class with a basis of knowledge on the subject that was to be discussed that day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures themselves were often quite interesting. The humor and style of the presentations were fun as well. The sensitivity and content with which the professors approached religious topics made for a good learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the split lectures and how every class I felt like I was being taught by an expert in the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors took us to the rare book library and used slides, videos, and worksheets to facilitate our learning. The trip to the rare book library was interesting and should be kept because it was super cool to see and have access to those ancient materials (it also gives exposure to the library for those who may not know it exists). The slides helped guide learning as well. The energy of the teachers helped facilitate learning. You can tell that they are enthusiastic about their work and sharing what they have worked on for so long. Their extensive knowledge in their respective subject field was helpful!I appreciated how understanding the professors about turning in assignments late and extenuating circumstances. I also appreciated how much prof mclarney would reach out and affirm me of my work and that I was doing well b/c I was unsure of my performance

response_text: Engage with Professor Sun! She is so nice and will take you to new levels of teaching if you engage with the course. course: RELIGION-257S-01 : FOUR FUNERALS AND A WEDDING.RELIGION-257S-01.AMES-257S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class provided a new perspective on examining religion, rather than the usual Eurocentric view. In terms of workload it's quite nice; you just write a brief weekly memo on the assigned readings. At the end, there is a final paper, which is a good opportunity to explore a question that's piqued your interest after starting the course.

course: RELIGION-257S-01 : FOUR FUNERALS AND A WEDDING.RELIGION-257S-01.AMES-257S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in the study of religion or Chinese culture, please take this class. This is a wonderful seminar class at an intermediate level. You will have the chance to challenge yourself without being stressed out too much. Dr. Anna Sun is a great professor because she is very knowledgeable and kind. You will really learn a lot in this class and have fun if you are interested in the topics covered in this course.

course: RELIGION-257S-01 : FOUR FUNERALS AND A WEDDING.RELIGION-257S-01.AMES-257S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great option for anyone who is interested in religions in China. It’s very well-structured and the reading selected by Prof. Anna Sun are very interesting and inspiring. The students will get very professional and careful academic training in this class. Prof. Anna Sun is super supportive and willing to help with any questions related to the class. It’s a great class.

course: RELIGION-257S-01 : FOUR FUNERALS AND A WEDDING.RELIGION-257S-01.AMES-257S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class discusses Chinese religions from a sociological standpoint. Do not be afraid to take this class if you are not religious or if you are not Asian, since Dr. Sun does a great job of making sure everyone is included in the conversation. There is one midterm proposal and a final research paper that are on the lengthier side but you have lots of time to work on it.

response_text: Definitely take it if you are interested in AMES! Also look for any other class with Professor Sun - I'm sure all of her classes are great.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go for it and you will not regret. As a Chinese, I came to realize that how ignorant I am to some religions or their special practices in China—and this course taught me a lot. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. sociology and methods
2. new way of studying and understanding Confucianism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I have learnt Confucianism in East Asia, which I had no relative knowledge before. This knowledge on East Asian Confucianism provides with inspiration on my own study.
2. Since students need to upload memos on the readings each week, it improves my writing skills and helps me to remember the topics of each class in the end of the semester.
3. The professor highly recommends the Duke Library website, and I find it truly useful for academic research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have acquired more knowledge of a vital component chaining the Asian history which may be taken for granted thus lack reflective illustrations in many studies. And I learned much about the idea of sacredness and spirits, and more importantly how to think and study them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Transnational spreading of Confucianism, ethnographical methodologies, religious factors and evaluations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've read about various insightful interpretations of Confucian classics and the relationship between traditional Confucian values and contemporary societies. Specifically, I'm especially impressed by the perspective of viewing Confucianism as a religion, which entails a very novel and persuasive definition of the term religion itself. I've also encountered many Confucian ritual practices which I've been familiar with in my past life, and gained completely new understandings of these rituals, especially ancestral worships. Third, I've been intrigued by a recent reading material discussing the "as-if" world created by ritual practices, with an emphasis on the gap between the Confucian ideal and the reality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me several close reading strategies not only for novels but for videos, films, and social media posts that completely changed the way I interact with media outside of this class. We also covered themes of racial inequality, revolutions, politics, ekphrasis, and so much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Strategies for close reading and analysis; this was helpful for engaging in academic texts that are in the humanities, which is a bit different than what I’m used to with reading research papersRecognizing how form effected content. A big part of this course was practicing the ability to recognize the subtle and implicit ways our senses are engaged through different mediums of content and how that impacts our interpretations and understandings.We looked a lot at different protests and strategies employed. Most interesting for me was looking at Egypt and Iran during the Arab Spring which is something I haven’t read much about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The structure of the class was rather simple but effective. Read and reflect on content and come to class to share and develop ideas on that content. I love this format of class because it is rather free flowing and engaging. 
The parts I disliked the most were ones that stymied that format, particularly the work sheets. I feel as though giving specific content guidelines and 1 question to answer or 1 purpose in a group setting would have been just as effective and more interesting.
